trustfund:
TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF023043-PHRD-URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE REHABILITATION,TF036160-TANZANIA - WATER SUPPLY AND
            SANITATION PROJECT,TF039820-MOZAMBIQUE - MUNICIPAL
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Urban Sector
            Rehabilitation Project for Tanzania were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: successful implementation depends on
            setting realistic development objectives, keeping the design
            of the project simple, and establishing practical
            implementation arrangements. Establishing base-line data for
            the key output/impact indicators for a project and tracking
            it over the implementation period will make quantitative
            information available. The current IDA staff was reportedly
            not acting as auditors to check where the government project
            staff has gone wrong. The supervision strategy for large
            infrastructure projects must be well structured and should
            be followed in a disciplined fashion, and include exhaustive
            site visits. Creation of autonomous Urban Water and Sewerage
            Authority (UWSAs) with ring-fenced revenue has proven to be
            an effective institutional arrangement for sustainable
            service delivery. Quality of work and improved services
            alter public perception. Good record keeping and timely
            processing of financial issues simplifies audits. Making
            Community contribution a condition of construction
            commencement in the urban setting could lead to delays.
            Importance of long-term framework and careful project
            preparation study. Effective conflict management minimizes
            cost and implementation delays.
